description: "In this historical survey, students learn to listen analytically, historically, and creatively to music from the Middle Ages to the present day. A wide range of musical repertories including plainchant, opera, orchestral music, and chamber music is covered. Composers studied include Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Verdi, and Wagner. No prior musical knowledge is required.
name: 1000 YRS MUSICAL LISTENG

values.comments:
This class is designed to explore why music moves listeners and what we find enjoyable about music, while also investigating what it is you hear when listening to music. It aims to introduce students to a variety of music, and a range of ways of thinking, talking and writing about music.  The majority of music dealt with is drawn from the so-called "Classical" repertory, from the medieval period to the present day, including some of the 'greats' such as Handel, Beethoven, Mozart, Berlioz, and Verdi, but also introduces a student to unfamiliar music. This course explores the technical workings of music and the vocabularies for analyzing music and articulating a response to it; it also examines music as a cultural phenomenon, considering what music has meant for different people, from different societies across the ages and across geographical boundaries. Students listen to music and also engage with a history of listening. No prior musical knowledge is required. 

Students describe this course as interesting, enjoyable, and engaging. All students reviewed reported learning a lot and enjoying the course. One student felt that the course helped all students to “develo[p] as experience music listeners, all while having an entertaining time in class.” One student felt enlightened by the course—others agreed, noting that they learned significant amounts about music from the last century—although some students offered a critique that the course did not focus on technical aspects as much as it could have. 

All students reported that Professor Dolan is an engaging and good teacher. According to one student, Professor Dolan is “wonderful instructor, who is not only an engaging lecturer, but is totally willing to discuss music anytime, anywhere. Her passion for music shows in every aspect of the course.” Students agreed that Professor Dolan was interesting, enthusiastic, passionate, and knowledgeable. “I strongly believe that Professor Dolan is one of the finest at Penn,” another student wrote. As another student explained, “Professor Dolan is great at presenting the information to students who have little musical background, and she excels at presenting it in a compelling way. I have little interest in music, but Professor Dolan was able to hold my interest the majority of the time. She is a great professor.”

As the course requires listening quizzes, listening responses, concert review, exams, and reading, many students felt the work could be significant, but worth it. As one student described it, “There are a lot of assignments, but I found most of them useful in terms of increasing the overall amount of learning I took away from the class.” Students also agreed that the grading was extremely fair, one noting that the grading was distributed across the assignments so that no one assignment is worth more than 20-25%. Many students would recommend the course, even to students not interested in music. This course satisfies the Arts & Letters Sector.
